titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Saturday.

Hail— Sleet. Snow— This was the succession of weather throughout the day. I called at the War Department, and left with the Secretary, Cass, a Certificate of Edward D. Bangs the Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts that Thomas Burgess served as a Soldier in the Revolutionary War upwards of two years— Dr Zacheus Bartlett sent it to me, with a view to obtain for Burgess a Military Land Warrant.— He also made enquiries, for a discharge of John Barton, another Revolutionary Soldier, given by him to a Lieutt. Robert Bradford, of whom he has seen or heard nothing since— Mr Cass took minutes of the names which I gave him from Dr Bartlett’s Letter, and promised to have the proper enquiries made, and to inform me of the result— I then left Cards for Mr M’Duffie, and John M. Felder, members of the House from South-Carolina, and sat for my Portrait to Rembrandt Peale— I had promised him a sitting last Saturday, but was confined to the house by Indisposition— I sat now about half an hour, when Mr Frelinghuysen, a Senator from New-Jersey came by a previous engagement— I promised Mr Peale another sitting next Saturday unless as is most probable
the House should on that day be in Session— Mr Peale has got a better Portrait of me, than any that has ever been painted excepting that of Copley in 1796. and the full length by Stewart in 1825— I rode home, and in the Evening began a Letter to Charles.
2. V:30. Sunday.

The ground covered by about nine inches of Snow; a clear day, and vernal atmosphere At St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read Prayers for Sexagesima Sunday and preached in the Morning from Psalm 19.2. “Day unto day uttereth Speech, and night unto Night sheweth knowledge.” And in the afternoon from Romans 8.7. “Because the carnal mind is enmity against God: for it is not subject to the law of God, neither indeed can be.” This is the text upon which Mr Smith of the Presbyterian Church, has preached a series of discourses. Mr Hawley’s conclusions are always the same, whatever his text may be— This morning he gave the whole chapter of the Prisoner from Sterne’s Sentimental Journey, as a quotation to present a parallel between the fate of this Prisoner, and that which the Sinner must expect in the other world— This afternoon he said it was a melancholy thing to consider how totally religion was neglected by most of the persons who stood the highest in the honours and power of the Nation— I answered this Evening a Letter, received from Abbott Lawrence of Boston. A Bill for the annexation of Penalties to the Administration of unlawful Oaths, is in discussion before the Legislature of Massachusetts— And also a Bill for altering the manner of electing members of the House of Representatives of the United States— Both these measures were most earnestly recommended by me, in my Address to the People— But so sure is every thing recommended by me to meet with insuperable opposition, that I cannot yet flatter myself with the hope that either of these measures will be effectively carried through.
3. V. Monday.

Day for Petitions. Gorham Parks of Maine presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Maine approving the removal of the deposits from the Bank of the United States, and against the recharter of that Institution; and he made a Speech commenting upon the exalted character of the State, and of its Legislature— Then F. O. J. Smith presented Resolutions of a large popular Meeting at Portland, representing their distress, and calling for a restoration of the deposits; and Smith made a Speech against the very Resolutions that he presented— George Evans of Maine in a short Speech answered both his Colleagues— Evans is one of the ablest men in the house. Polk of Tennessee made a Speech in the dictatorial tone telling the House that they must at the latest decide the question of referring the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury on the removal of the deposits to the Committee of Ways and Means tomorrow— He was called to order by Mr Gorham— Dudley Selden, one of the four Members from the City of New-York, presented a petition of 3500 commercial houses, signed by more than 6000 persons, setting forth their distress, and the disordered state of the Currency; and praying for a national bank— Selden made a Speech of about an hour and a half, on presenting the petition— Objection was made to his proceeding, but the rule was suspended to allow him to go on— He concluded by moving the reference of the petition to a select committee of five. R. H. Wilde of Georgia moved an Amendment of Instructions to enquire into the distress, investigate
its Causes, and propose the remedies— This gave rise to a very animated debate, which lasted till six O’Clock—in the course of which Selden accepted the Amendment offered by Wilde—but modified his motion for a Committee, so that it should consist of one Member from each State— Polk moved its reference to the Committee of Ways and Means, and by the rule of Order in taking Questions, that of reference to a standing Committee, precedes that for a select Committee— The simple reference to the Committee of Ways and Means was made by yeas and nays 113 to 97. Wilde of Georgia said to me, that my hope that this would come before the end of the Session, to be a lost Majority, was likely to be realized; but the operation would be slow— It was dark when the House adjourned; and my Evening was idle— I had called in the Morning at the Post-Office, with a Letter from F. A. Kingsbury of Weymouth concerning a claim of Mr Linfield, a Mail contractor— The Postmaster General was not there, but Mr Hobbie promised to look into the Matter and send me a Letter.
4. V:30: Tuesday.

In the House, Mr Chilton’s Resolution of enquiry for extending the Pension system was taken up and Patrick H. Pope of Kentucky made a Speech of about half an hour, in its favour— Eloquent after the Western Style— T. T. Bouldin and David Crockett rose together— The Speaker gave the floor to Crockett, if he was going to make a Speech— Crockett said his object was to move the previous question— The Speaker said that was not in order, Mr Bouldin having already the floor. Crockett said then he would make a short Speech himself, which he did— I then said I wished for about ten minutes to address the House; not upon Mr Bouldin’s Amendment, nor until that should be disposed of; but as that might be cut off by the previous question, which had been threatened, and which if carried would deprive me of the opportunity of speaking on the main Resolution, I must claim the floor in preference to Mr Bouldin, who had once spoken, upon his Amendment. I accordingly obtained the floor and spoke for the remainder of the hour, not exceeding ten Minutes in favour of the Resolution, much to the Satisfaction of several of the Western Members, two or three of whom, expressly thanked me for my Speech; and one of them asked to be introduced to me for that purpose. John B. Forester of Tennesee. But my Speech was nothing, and ought to have been a strong one— There came a thundering Message of the President upon the conduct of the Bank of the United States, in refusing to deliver up the Books and to transfer monies in Bank, appropriated for the payment of Pensioners under the act of June 1832, which occasioned a very sharp debate— Motion was immediately made to refer the Message and accompanying documents to the Committee of Ways and Means. Coll Watmough moved their reference to the Committee on the Judiciary— There was a Letter from the President of the Bank, containing an argument upon the Law, and a counter-argument in an opinion of the Attorney General, Butler, with the Message— Barringer called for the reading of these papers—and the question to which Committee the reference should be made was debated till past five O’Clock— Denny of Pennsylvania moved Instructions to the Committee, for payment to the Pensioners but his Amendment was cut off by the previous-Question. carried by 119 to 95— And then the simple reference to the Committee of Ways and Means
was decided, by a vote of 107 to 106— After giving my vote on this last question, I left the House and came home while the yeas and nays were taking— The house immediately afterwards adjourned— We had company to dine; and in the Evening Mr Clark, and Mr Slade remained with me, about an hour, conversing upon the Prospects of the Anti-Masonic party— They have been nearly annihilated by the desertion of R. Rush— Coll. Crockett was very diverting at our dinner— Mr Bell Senator from New-Hampshire failed to come—
5. IV. Wednesday.

Dr Huntt this morning bled Mrs Adams who is quite unwell. At the House Mr Binney shewed me a joint Resolution which he proposed to offer directing that the Bank of the United States should make payment to the Pensioners of their Pensions, so far as they have public funds for the purpose, and until the question of Law between the Bank and the Secretary of War shall be settled.— In the House, the General Appropriation Bill was reported by Polk, the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, and then, till the expiration of the first hour, Bills at the third reading were taken up, and a number of them were passed— After the hour, the deposit question came up, and the Speaker called up Archer, when M’Kinley of Alabama, asked him to yield the floor to him for a moment as he had a notice to give to the house— Archer assented and M’Kinley said there had been debate enough upon this subject— That it was necessary to come to some decision, and he hoped immediately after Archer should finish his Speech, the House would take the question, and there he got down— I rose to speak; the Speaker asked Archer if he yielded the floor— I told him it was merely to remark on M’Kinley’s notice—and he gave me the floor— I asked what was the notice given by the member from Alabama? The Speaker answered that I had heard what he had said— I said I had heard him announce that he had a notice to give to the house; and then I had heard him say, that immediately after Mr Archer should finish his Speech, the House must take the question— Was that the Gentleman’s notice? The Speaker laughed. M’Kinley made no reply, and I sat down— Archer resumed his Speech, and spoke about an hour, without a Quorum in the House. I asked Mr Gorham, if he did not intend to speak— He said no—he had given it up, and should wait for the report of the Committee— When Archer finished however, there were three or four claimants for the floor. It was taken by Bailey Peyton of Tennessee— He had been conning his Speech for a long time, for it was chiefly in answer to M’Duffie— Very declamatory, and full of invective— In the course of half an hour he became exhausted, and before B. Bell of Tennessee moved an adjournment, in his behalf— The house immediately adjourned. I went into the Senate chamber which was crowded, and where Mr Clay was speaking— Between him and Silas Wright, and Wilkins and Webster, and Sprague there was a sharp-shooting debate on the mere question whether 5000 or 6000 copies should be printed of the Report of the Committee of Finance, on the Secretary of Treasury’s Deposit report— It was made this morning by Mr Webster, and the debate upon it was very acrimonious— I asked Mr Bell, the Senator from New Hampshire how it happened that he had not dined with us yesterday— He said he had waited until after the adjournment of the House, and had then not been able to procure a Carriage— The weather was warm as Spring and disqualified me for both reading and writing— Hence an idle evening.
6. IV.15. Thursday.

At the House, I offered by unanimous consent a Resolution that the Committee of Commerce be instructed to enquire and report upon the expediency of making Dorchester in the State of Massachusetts a Port of Delivery—which was adopted. George Chambers of Pennsylvania, made a very earnest Speech against Chilton’s Resolution for extending the Pension system— The hour expired and he had not finished. Pinckney of South-Carolina moved to suspend the rule that Chambers might conclude, but the House refused— The deposit question then came up, and Bailey Peyton finished his Speech to the honour and Glory of Andrew Jackson against M’Duffie’s Speech— He was followed by Henry A Wise, a new and young member from Virginia who made a very keen, satirical Speech, in favour of the restoration of the deposits and of a National Bank, and against all those who are of the same opinions— He is coming forward as a successor of John Randolph; with his tartness—his bitterness, his malignity and his inconsistencies— Wise finished at about half past three when T. T Bouldin obtained the floor and moved an adjournment— Immediately came a call for the yeas and nays, which explained M’Kinley’s notice of yesterday—but the Majority are not yet screwed up to stop the debate. The adjournment was carried by a vote of 113 to 103— Coll. Crockett introduced me a young man by the name of Clark who he said was one of his Constituents— Mary dined abroad at Mrs W. S Smith’s and John was abroad this Evening— The President had a Drawing-room.
7. IV:15. Friday.

At the House of Representatives I met Asbury Dickins and asked him why the Resolution of the House calling on the President for a List of Presents, deposited at the Department of State had not been answered— He said that it had not been received— I asked the Clerk of the House whether it had not been sent to the President; he said it was not yet passed by the House— I said the Journal had then been falsified— Johnson the assistant Clerk looked over the minute of the Journal and said I was right, and that the Resolution had passed by unanimous consent— This however was only one mistake for another— It was not passed by unanimous consent when offered, but as I thought laid over one day and then adopted without opposition— Even of this I am not sure, for I was confident I had a minute of it and found I had not— I was rash and violent in the charge of falsification of the Journal— Dickins asked me, whether I thought the written opinions which by the Constitution the President is authorised to require from the Heads of Departments, are public Papers, liable to be called for by either house of Congress. I said I thought they were, and referred him to the Documents of the first Session of the last Congress upon the apportionment Law among which are the opinions given to President Washington, by the Heads of the Departments, upon the first Apportionment act, which he negatived. I thought Dickins meant to give me a hint, that there were written opinions, given by the Heads of Departments to the present President, which it might be desirable to have called for. In the House T. Chilton’s Resolution was up, and Chambers of Pennsylvania finished his Speech, an elaborate one, against it— G. W. Lay obtained the floor on the
same side of the question but the hour had expired— Polk, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means moved to suspend the rule of private business to take up the partial Appropriation Bill—the Rule was accordingly suspended— M’Intyre’s motion to reconsider the vote rejecting the Report of the Committee of Conference gave rise to much debate— Wilde’s motion to recede which the Speaker first decided not to be out of order, and the next day after M’Intyre’s motion to reconsider was made, he declared had been in order, ought to have been first debated— But the Speaker gave the preference to the motion to reconsider— It was warmly contested, but the House refused to reconsider by yeas and nays 115 to 103— Wilde of Georgia then moved to recede from the House’s disagreement to the Amendment of the Senate, and this raised another sharp debate, Polk pleading piteously for another Conference— The vote to recede was carried by yeas and nays 111 to 104. and the Bill is passed— A motion was made to adjourn over to Monday; but it was objected to and a few votes were wanting of two thirds to suspend the rule— Several private Bills at the third reading were passed, and the House between 3. and 4. adjourned— Jotham Lincoln is to call on me to-morrow.
8. IV.15. Saturday.

Mr Lincoln called this morning called upon me, and shewed me several papers in support of his claim. A Bill for his relief has passed the House of Representatives, but labours before the Committee of Claims of the Senate. The same Bill has more than once passed the House before. Mr Lincoln is much discouraged, and wishes to go home. I advised him to shew his papers to Mr Webster and Mr Silsbee, and to ask their influence in support of his claim, and I thought it would be of no use for him after that to stay here any longer— At the House Mr Binney brought me the Report unfavourable to the claim of Weston Allen and Co. which he made some weeks since, for the Committee of Claims— It was a petition for a remission of duties on a quantity of damaged rum found afloat at Sea, and the duties upon which amounted to more than the Article sold for— Mr Binney thinks the case without remedy— Sundry Resolutions were received by unanimous consent— Chilton’s Resolution about the Pensions came up and Mr G. W. Lay spoke about half an hour against it— He was some what agitated, but spoke very handsomely and sensibly— Private Bills were then discussed, and several of them passed without debate— A Bill for the relief of the legal Representatives of Arnold Henry Dohrmann was however contested, but finally passed— The House adjourned between 3 and 4.— In the Evening I paid a visit to my neighbour Mrs Tudor, who has recently returned to her Residence here, from New-York.
9. IV:30. Sunday

Attended this Morning at the Presbyterian Church and heard Mr Smith from Isaiah 58.3—latter part of the verse—“Behold, in the day of your fast ye find pleasure, and exact all your labours.” He gave notice that there would be to-morrow Evening at Dr Post’s Church, a Sabbath-School Association Meeting, at which Mr Frelinghuysen and Mr Pinckney of South-Carolina would deliver Addresses— He also gave
notice that there would be no service by him this afternoon, in consequence of some association meeting at Dr Laurie’s Church this Evening. After the Service I had a visit from Mr Isaac M’Kim, now the Representative from Baltimore, who spoke to me much upon the Bank controversy, but hardly seemed to know what he thought about it— He promised me, and afterwards sent me a pamphlet of David Ricardo—a Plan for the Establishment of a National Bank, in England— In the Afternoon at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening prayer for Quinquagesima Sunday—and a Stranger preached from Matthew 10.32 “Whosoever therefore shall confess me before men, him will I confess also before my father which is in Heaven. 33. But whosoever shall deny me before men, him will I also deny before my father which is in Heaven”— My wife continues quite unwell, and is confined to her chamber
10. IV:15. Monday.

I called at the Department of State, and left with Asbury Dickins now Chief Clerk there, the Letter from Reuben Baldwin, with the prize of an old Lottery ticket of the year 1780. and enquired if he knew any thing of such a ticket or Lottery. He had never heard of it, but promised to make enquiry— He said they had now received the Resolution calling for the list of presents— At the House in calling over the States for Petitions, the Speaker began with New-York—at which the call of last Monday was arrested by the debate on the Memorial then presented by Selden— Cambreleng now presented four Memorials, and accompanied them with an inflammatory Speech— One was for the establishment of a Warehousing System, upon which Cambreleng uttered an invective upon the Tarriff-Act of July 1832. one of his Memorials was from the Tammany Democrats against the Restoration of the Deposits and the rechartering of the Bank of the United States. He said it was signed by ten thousand persons— But Selden read one of their Resolutions which was suppressed in the Memorial—and which squinted at a National Bank to be located at New-York— Selden presented also a Counter-memorial signed by 2000 tradesmen, and Mechanics, complaining of distress, and praying for the restoration of the deposits— From Pennsylvania, Muhlenberg presented a Memorial from Lancaster against the re-chartering of the Bank, and H. Denny, a Memorial from the same County, in favour of the Bank. Denny supports his memorial with a warm Speech— H. Binney presented a Memorial from 10259. Merchants, tradesmen and Mechanics of Philadelphia, praying for the restoration of the deposits, and bitterly complaining of distress— Mr Binney made a short Speech in support of his memorial. Sutherland presented two Memorials, one for and one against the Bank and the restoration of the deposits— He made few remarks. Watmough presented two Memorials one for, and the other against the Bank from the third Congressional District, being that represented by him— He moved the reference of the first, without reading to the Committee of Ways and Means— It was so referred. He made the same motion for the second, but Speight of North-Carolina called for the reading of it, and it was read— There was a string of Resolutions hot and hot against the Bank, and in honour of Andrew Jackson— Watmough then asked for the reading of the first Memorial and Resolutions— The Speaker said it was too late— They were
already referred— Watmough moved a suspension of the rule, which was refused. He moved a reconsideration of the reference of the first Memorial—refused 88 to 102— When the Speaker called for the Territory of Florida, White the Delegate asked leave of the House to offer a Resolution—objection was made— He moved a suspension of the Rule—it was suspended, and his Resolution was received— When Massachusetts was called I presented the Petition of John Marshall, President, and others, Officers of the Washington National Monument Society, praying for an Act of Incorporation: And it was at my motion referred to the Judiciary Committee. It had been given to me, by Mr Waterston with a request that I would present it and move its reference to that Committee— Judge Cranch had also given me a Bill ready drawn to hand over to the Committee— After the reference of the Petition, I asked leave to offer a Resolution— Objection was made— I observed that the House had suspended the rule, to allow the Delegate from Florida to offer a Resolution, and I must ask of them the same indulgence— The rule was suspended— My Resolution was received and laid over— It was for a 58th. rule for transacting business in the house, making it the duty of the Committee of Ways and Means to report the Annual Appropriation Bills within thirty days after their appointment—the House adjourned about half past three— Mr L. P. Dennis of Maryland introduced his Colleague William Cost Johnson to me at my request; but I found he was not as my wife had supposed him to be of the family of Governor Johnson— Beardsley of New-York came and enquired of me concerning the depretiation of paper money during the Revolutionary War— I gave him such information as was in my power— As I was walking home I was accosted by a person who said his name was James L Adams and asked me if I had not received from the West, Letters intended for him— I had received one such Letter directed to New-York last June, and lately sent to me, from the General Post-Office as a dead Letter— It was from Detroit in the Michigan Territory, and he said it was for him— I wrote two short Letters this Evening— Mr Leaming one of the delegates from Philadelphia, with the memorial walked with me from the Capitol to Gadsby’s where he lodged.
11. IV:15. Tuesday.

At the House, among the Reports from standing Committees was one made by Mr Polk Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, with a Bill for the payment of the Pensioners— Ordered that ten thousand copies of the report and Documents be printed. I moved a Reconsideration of the vote yesterday taken, referring one of the Memorials from New-York presented yesterday by Mr Cambreleng, to the Committee of Ways and Means, with a view to move its reference to the Committee of Manufactures. It was the one praying for the Establishment of a Warehousing System— I said the Memorial had not been read, and being now at the Printers I had not been able to get a sight of it, but from the observations made by the Gentleman who presented it, there could be no doubt that the measure prayed for by the Memorial would deeply
affect the manufacturing interest; for the protection of which the Committee to which I belonged was instituted— The Speaker said the Consideration of my Motion must be laid over till next Monday— I said that if the reference of the Memorial was to be made to the Committee of Manufactures, it was important that it should be made as speedily as possible, and asked the unanimous consent of the house to consider the motion now— But objection was made— I moved to suspend the rules for which a considerable majority voted, but not two thirds, so that the motion was lost— Then Chilton’s Resolution for extending the Pension system, with Bouldin’s Amendment were called up— Chilton Allan of Kentucky said he was very desirous of replying to the Arguments of several Gentlemen against the Resolution, and a member from Georgia. (Gilmer) had also claimed the floor in opposition to it— But the House was weary of the debate, and he was willing to forego the privilege of further addressing the House on the Resolution, and would do, what he had never done before, move the previous Question. This of course cut off Bouldin’s Amendment, and Allan was requested to withdraw his motion, but declined— There was a large second for the previous Question—which was carried by a large majority by yeas and nays, 136 to 66 as was the question upon the Resolution itself 119 to 87 The Committee to consist of nine members. The hour expired— The motion for reference of the Secretary of the Treasury’s Report on the removal of the deposits to the Committee of Ways and Means; with the Instructions moved by M’Duffie, and the Amendment proposed by S. Jones of Georgia came up. T. T. Bouldin of Virginia had the floor, from last Thursday, and a long and impressive Speech was expected from him— He rose and said that before entering upon the subject in debate, he would notice a rebuke he had received from his Colleague who had last spoken (Wise) for the omission to offer the usual Resolution that the House should go into mourning for the decease of John Randolph, who at the time of his Death, had been a member elect of this House (Randolph died last June, and Bouldin was chosen to succeed him—) He said he had no disposition to take to himself any general reflections which might equally apply to others, but thought he could not avoid some reply to a censure, which could apply to no other person than himself— That it would have been kind if his colleague instead of this public animadversion upon his omission had enquired of him privately the reason for it— That another of his Colleagues had done so in the most delicate manner, and through a third person, at the commencement of the Session— And now to justify himself before this House, his Colleagues and his Constituents it was necessary for him to say, what he should have said, if he had offered such a Resolution— At this instant Mr Bouldin shook, staggered and fell, and never spoke another word— He was taken as soon as possible without the bar, laid on the carpet close to a window which was thrown up— The House was instantly adjourned. Two or three physicians, members of the House, and Dr Naudain of the Senate hastened to his aid— He was immediately bled, but died within fifteen minutes— His wife was in the Gallery where she had come to hear him speak— She came down immediately
after he fell, quite in a state of distraction— There was a moment of interval when he had an appearance of returning life, which was told her to compose her agitation, but two minutes after, he expired—her friends were obliged to take her away, screaming in agony. I saw him within five minutes after the Spirit had departed; and the corpse was soon after removed into the Speaker’s chamber— I had gone over from my Seat, to say a word to Mr Beardsley, while Mr Bouldin was speaking, and had my eyes upon him as he was speaking his last words— I had but just turned from looking in his face, when I heard a member say—“he is greatly agitated”— I looked towards him, and he was already fallen— As I walked home, I mused on the frailty of human life, and the vicissitudes of human passions and fortunes—but especially on the tenderness with which the feelings and judgments and motives of others ought to be treated in political debate— Mr Bouldin was a man of good dispositions and sterling integrity; warped sometimes into great curvature by the political prejudices of the Virginia School— He had been bitter as gall upon all the Tariff questions, and the Proclamation and the removal of the deposits had brought him round to determined opposition to the present Administration— His Speech would have been one of the severest against the administration to which the debate has given rise; and the Catastrophe which intercepted it is but one of the symptoms of intense excitement spreading over the community
12. IV:30. Ash Wednesday.

Dr Huntt and Mr Radcliff of New-York were here this morning. Radcliff about his projected Railway and Ship Canal across the Isthmus of Panama. Anxious to ascertain whether the Administration here would give countenance or encouragement to it— I was satisfied they would not— Walking to the Capitol I met judge Hopkinson of Philadelphia who went with me to the House— Immediately after the reading of the Journal, W. S. Archer of Virginia rose, and after an affecting allusion to the Catastrophe of yesterday, and a handsome tribute of respect to the memory of his deceased Colleague, Thomas Tyler Bouldin, offered the usual Resolutions for wearing crape thirty days, and attending the funeral at 11. O’Clock to-morrow Morning. and those Resolutions having been adopted He moved the House to adjourn which they accordingly did— I went into the Supreme Court, where the Attorney General B. F. Butler was arguing some cause— I invited R. Peters to dine with us, but he was engaged. As I was walking home Mr Leaming of Philadelphia overtook me in a Carriage, and I rode with him home— Judge Hopkinson dined with us— It was my wife’s birthday.
13. IV. Thursday.

The House met at 11. O’Clock and immediately after the reading of the Journal was adjourned to 12 to-morrow.— The funeral service over the remains of Thomas Tyler Bouldin, a member of the House from Virginia was performed by the Chaplains of the two Houses. The service of the Episcopal Church was read by Mr Stockton, the Chaplain
of the House, and an extemporaneous funeral Sermon was delivered by Mr Hatch, the Chaplain of the Senate— His text was Psalm 89.48. “What man is he that liveth, and shall not see death”— The certainty of Death, and the uncertainty of its time are familiar topics, upon which nothing new can be said, and where the event had been so awful, perhaps no extemporaneous comment upon it could otherwise than fall short of an impression corresponding with it— I rode to the Eastern Branch graveyard in a hack with John Adams, Charles Bodle and George W. Lay— The Carriage was a very small one, so that four persons could with difficulty be crowded into it, and the road was deep— In returning it stuck at the passage of a small wooden bridge, and we were all obliged to alight in the mud— I would not go into it again, but in walking homeward was overtaken by another Carriage in which were Martin Beatty of Kentucky, and William C. Dunlap of Tennessee, who offered me a seat with them which I accepted—returned to the Capitol, and thence walked home— Met Mr and Mrs Webster on my way— Mr John Connell of Philadelphia spent the Evening with us.
14. IV:30. Friday.

Mr Cowperthwait one of the Cashiers of the Bank of the United States was here this morning, and again in the Evening, with Mr Elihu Chauncey, who is at the head of a deputation of 24 persons from the numerous Petitioners of the Philadelphia Memorial for the restoration of the Public Deposits to the Bank of the United States— There have been similar Deputations from New-York and Baltimore— They have all had interviews with the President, who treated them all politely but declared his irrevocable determination, never to consent to the restoration of the deposits; and never to assent to the Chartering of a Bank of the United States— His experiment is to stake the Revenue, the credit and the currency of the Country upon the State Banks— At the House immediately after the reading of the Journal, Mr Wise of Virginia, by unanimous consent of the House gave an explanation of his remarks, upon which judge Bouldin was about to comment, when he fell, lifeless upon the floor— Mr Wise disclaimed all intention of hurting the feelings of Mr Bouldin when he made the observations to which the judge alluded in his last words— Mr Wise said an explanation had already taken place between them and that not the slightest sentiment of unkindness had remained between them after it— He eulogized Mr Bouldin with becoming sensibility—and redeemed in the apparent estimation of the House, the indiscretion, which had been imputed to him for his severity, after the fatal Catastrophe which seemed to have some connection with it. A Message from the President of the United States was received with a Report from the Secretary of State and a List of Presents received by Persons in the Public Service of the United States from any foreign King, Prince or State, and now deposited at the Department of State— This was the answer to a Call offered by me, and at my Motion the Message and Documents were ordered to be printed and referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs. Archer the Chairman promised me that he would wait till the other Resolution offered by me, and now before the House shall be acted upon, to make the Report from the Committee. The Resolution is a call for copies of the Instruction to R. Rush of
6. Novr 1817. and of President Jackson’s orders to the Agents abroad against receiving presents in any case.— There was a Resolution offered by Dixon H. Lewis sometime since, for making enquiries concerning certain Indian Treaties.— M’Kinley of Alabama moved it should be laid on the Table which it was by yeas and nays 107 to 88.— After the expiration of the hour, private Bills were taken up at the third reading and several were passed.— Committee of the whole on the Bill making Appropriations for fortifications G. M Briggs in the Chair—after a few questions reported without Amendment, and passed to be engrossed for a third reading— Adjourned after four
15. IV:30. Saturday.

Mr Potts, a member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania came with six other Gentlemen, from Chester and Lancaster Counties in that State— Mr Leaming and Mr M’Ilvaine with four others from Philadelphia soon followed; and then Mr Richards the late Mayor of that City— These are most or all delegates from the Memorialists to Congress, for relief which they will not obtain— They are in a state of great discouragement— But it is the spirit of fear, and not of resentment— At the House, a Resolution offered by George R. Gilmer of Georgia came up, calling upon the Secretary of War, for a Correspondence relating to the death of a man named Owens killed in the State of Alabama; by a soldier of the United States troops— It is a part of the sham quarrel between the Government of the State of Alabama, and the President of the United States— Mr Gilmer supported his Resolution with an ardent Speech— Clay of Alabama moved to lay the Resolution on the Table— Four Claimants for the floor were up—but the Hour for Resolutions had expired, and a motion to suspend the rule, for a continuance of the debate was lost— Several Bills at the third reading were passed, but the House refused to take up the Appropriation Bills, and it was impossible to get up a debate upon any thing else— The House adjourned about 2 O:Clock. I had urged Mr Binney to prepare a minority Report for the Committee of Ways and Means—there being a Resolution before the House for printing ten thousand Copies of the Report of the Majority— He intimated that there were difficulties in the minority of the Committee itself—that Mr Gorham has his own opinions— Wilde does not attend the Committee at all— Binney said he should have to sign the minority Report alone, and that r Gorham and Mr Webster were afraid of the effect of this affair upon the popularity of the Bank— I could not conceive this and asked Binney if this was not identical with the Deposit question besides something more— He thought with me, and has prepared a Report which he sent me by Mr Sergeant and requested me to read and return it to him to-morrow Morning. We had a company of members of Congress to dine with
us—somewhat mixed with regard to politics— Our Ladies preferred not to dine with us. The Conversation was miscellaneous— Mr Mercer who was to have been of the company, was confined at home by illness— I could read only a part of Mr Binney’s Minority Report this Evening.
16. III.30. Sunday.

I had scarcely any Sleep, and rose at half past three this Morning. I read the remainder of Mr Binney’s minority report; with some additional pages, which he brought and left at my house this morning— I took the manuscript back to his lodgings, before Church, but had time only for a few words of conversation with him concerning it— I heard this morning at the Presbyterian Church Mr Smith from Daniel 5.27—“Thou art weighed in the balances and art found wanting.” After the Sermon he gave notice that there would be a monthly sale of effects, next Saturday to pay the debts of the Church, and he called most earnestly upon the members of the Society for contributions— There was an approach to an intimation that if they should neglect this intimation, he would be forced to leave them. And he particularly requested every individual member of the Society to pray every evening for a revival of the Spirit of Religion— There is great need of it— Indifference to religion and infidelity are vices which naturally spring from general peace and prosperity— We are deeply infected with them, and they are spreading with frightful rapidity. May God in his Mercy and in his own due time provide the remedy! Mr Daniel Brent was here after the morning service— Mr Asbury Dickins has his place as Chief Clerk of the Department of State, and Mr Brent has been appointed Consul at Paris— He says he is to sail in April. After dinner, at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening Service for the first Sunday in Lent, and preached from Romans 12.2. “And be not conformed to this world; but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect will of God”— The discourse was very short, the communion having been administered in the Morning.— I employed part of the Evening in writing.
17. IV:30 Monday.

Rainy day. I rode to and from the Capitol— It was the day for Petitions and Memorials— But my motion to reconsider the reference to the Committee of Ways and Means of the Memorial from New-York praying for the establishment of a Warehouse system, was first taken up. I supported it by a few remarks, but my voice was so hoarse and feeble that it broke repeatedly, and I could scarcely articulate— It is gone forever; and it is in vain for me to contend against the decay of time and nature, and the incurable misconstruction of the House. Cambreleng resisted the motion— I was sustained by Huntington, and Selden was willing to reconsider but wished the memorial to go to the Committee of Commerce, to which I had no objection—but the House by yeas and nays 84 to 126 refused to reconsider— Then came Memorials from Portsmouth, New-Hampshire, presented by Harper, who made a Speech against it—from Providence Rhode-Island by Burges, who made a Speech in support of it, and was answered by Pearce, his Colleague—a sharp altercation between them succeeded— From Connecticut by Foot with a few remarks— By Cambreleng from New-York. Tammany Resolutions against the Bank— By King, Harper and Sutherland from Pennsylvania— Harper’s from Shoemaker’s which he supports with a Speech—
Among Sutherland’s Memorials there was a counter one from Shoemaker’s to that presented by Harper, and some words passed between them— One of the Sutherland’s Memorials was accompanied with Resolutions violent against the Government that is, the President— Mann of New-York objected to the printing of them, as containing disrespectful expressions to the Government— He asked for the reading again of the 2d. Resolution to mark the disrespectful expressions, but they were not there— He asked the reading of the 3d. and they were still not there— Sutherland intimated to Mann that he had better withdraw his objection, and whisperers flocked to him till he did withdraw it— Watmough took fire and said he was very sorry he had withdrawn it— He asked him what he meant by the Government? and said he would read to him the expressions which had given him offence; and he did read them— They were sharp enough— The Speaker called Watmough to order, but he persisted— Mann said he meant by the Government the House of Representatives, but admitted that the words read by Watmough were those he had thought exceptionable, and they referred only to the President. Mann backed out rather ungraciously and concluded with a declaration of personal Independence of Watmough— Lane of Indiana was for bringing the House upon Watmough but the Speaker put him down, by saying there was nothing before the House to reflect upon. Heath of Baltimore County presented a numerously signed deposit Memorial from Baltimore which he supported with a very warm speech declaring himself a firm friend and supporter of General Jackson, but no collar man— He said if the President were to send a message here to-morrow recommending the restoration of the deposits, the whole house would vote for it upon which he was called to order by the Speaker— Patton of Virginia presented a Memorial and Resolutions from Richmond, against the removal of the deposits and made an ambiguous speech against the Resolutions— From North-Carolina there were Resolutions against the removal of the deposits passed at a Meeting where S. P. Carson presided with considerable ability. Resolutions of the House of Representatives of Kentucky against the removal of the deposits were presented, and Lyon presented a Memorial signed he said by 33 persons to the same effect— He presented also a memorial from others, pretenders to the discovery of endless life on Earth—asking for Land. Pinckney of South-Carolina presented a Memorial from a large Meeting at Charleston South-Carolina, against the removal of the Deposits, but reserving the question of the constitutionality of the Bank. These memorials and debates with other Petitions kept the House in Session till half past five— Several attempts to adjourn were made but failed until all the States had been gone through— It was about six when I got home, exhausted and dispirited; and I could do nothing but play whist all the evening. This universal cry of distress from Portsmouth to Charleston and from Baltimore to Frankfort Kentucky, produces no appearance of a disposition to afford relief. I stopped this morning at Mr Wirt’s lodgings to enquire how he was— He is at the point of death with an attack of Erisypelas.— At the House I saw Mr. John Barney who told me he had just come from Mr Wirt’s. He had a blister on the head but was not expected to survive.
18. IV. Tuesday.

Passing in my way to the Capitol this morning, by the house where Mr Wirt had lodged, a crape tied to the knocker of the door announced his decease; and thus pass away in succession the glories of this world— He has not left a wiser or better behind— At the last election of President of the United States, he was one of the Candidates who received the suffrages of the People, and a very little difference in the state of the public mind at that time would have effected his election— He had never been in public life, excepting in connection with his profession, which was the Law, but for twelve years during the Administration of James Monroe, and mine, he was Attorney-General of the United States— His death was announced to the Supreme Court by Mr Webster, with an appropriate Eulogy.

At the House upon the reading of the Journal I objected to the Statement on it respecting the Memorial from New-York for the Establishment of a Warehousing system, but the Speaker persisted in leaving the statement upon the Journal, without correction— The Resolution of Mr Gilmer of Georgia, respecting the killing of Owens was discussed till the expiration of the hour.— B. Gorham, presented the Minority Report from the Committee of Ways and Means, on the Bank and Pension fund Message— I took that opportunity to offer a Resolution calling for a Statement of facts and the Correspondence respecting the disallowance by the accounting Officers of the Treasury and of an account paid by the Bank of the United States; under an order from the Commissioner of Pensions.— My Resolution necessarily lies over a day.— When the deposit question came up, Henry A. Muhlenberg of Pennsylvania, after a Speech, moved the previous Question— Wilde of Georgia, and Burges of Rhode-Island, asked him to withdraw his motion, but he declined. Chilton of Kentucky moves a call of the House; which the Speaker declares to be not in order. Chilton appeals from the decision of the Speaker, but afterwards at the request of Harding of Kentucky, withdraws his Appeal, which I immediately renewed, and a discussion of an hour or more followed— I then withdrew my appeal, stating that although more and more convinced of the pernicious character of the decision, there were indications enough to me that the majority of the House would not now agree with me in opinion, and I preferred leaving the question for a propitious moment than to take now a vote which might hereafter appear to be a precedent against the principle which I deem correct— Foster of Georgia however renewed the appeal again, and the question was decided by yeas and nays— The Speaker’s decision was sustained by 115 to 112—which in the state of parties and the temper of the house was equivalent to a majority of 25 against it— Then upon the question of a second to the demand for the previous question the vote counted by Tellers was 116 to 109— Then voted by yeas and nays that the main question should be now putMotion to adjourn rejected by yeas and nays.and finally the main question being for a simple reference to the Committee of Ways and Means was carried by 130 to 98— The House adjourned, about half past 4 O’Clock— I dined with Mr Joseph M. White the Delegate from Florida. and a party among whom were judge Hopkinson and his Son James; judge Porter of Louisiana; the Senator General Ashley, member of the House from Missouri, Mr Smith the Register of the Treasury. F. C Gray, a Mr Waldron, R. M. Walsh, R. Peters, and some others— Mr Wilde of Georgia, and Mr Albuquerque Cavalcanti, the Brazilian Chargé d’Affaires, keep house with Mr White and were of the company. I had much conversation with judge Porterr, who sat next to me at table, and who has a taste for Literature English, French, and Classical, and whose opinions I found congenial to my own.
19. IV:30. Wednesday.

At the House a Resolution offered by Samuel W. Mardis of Alabama came up, upon which he spoke till the expiration of the hour without finishing— It proposed an instruction to the Secretary of the Treasury to distribute the public revenues in deposit among the several State Banks, and to prescribe a form of contract for such purposes, and it brings up again in another form the question of the deposits— There were several Bills reported by the standing Committees, and several taken up at the third reading.— A bill for the Settlement of the claims of Revolutionary Officers and Soldiers was postponed till next Tuesday— The Bill for continuing an Act of Congress of 1829. for furnishing supplies to the Army, after a long scattering debate was recommitted to the Committee of Military Affairs— The Appropriation Bill for Fortifications was at the third reading— Mr. M’Duffie moved to recommit the Bill to strike out all the Appropriations for new works— Barringer of North Carolina, and Brown of New York sustained him— B. Gorham E. Everett and Harper of Pennsylvania spoke in favour of the Appropriations for George’s Island, and Fort Delaware— Polk answered M’Duffie and Wayne; to whom M’Duffie replied— I rose to speak, but Briggs moved an adjournment, near four O’Clock, and it was carried.— I wrote in the Evening.
20. VI. Thursday

Morning visit from Judge Burnet, heretofore a member of the Senate from the State of Ohio, and Judge Pope, District judge of the United States in the State of Illinois— They are here in attendance upon the Supreme Court— I saw by the morning papers that the funeral of Mr Wirt was fixed, to proceed from his late dwelling at 12. O’Clock, precisely the hour of Meeting of the House. I went therefore with my Son John to the funeral, intending to follow the procession, until I should pass by the Capitol, and there alight to repair to my Station in the House— But they barely met, read the Journal, and adjourned at the motion of John Y. Mason, a member from Virginia who mentioned the funeral of Mr Wirt, and the wish of many members to attend it, as his inducement to make the motion— Warren R. Davis of South-Carolina, started an objection that there was no precedent—but it was not sustained— The House adjourned. The President, Vice-President, four Heads of the Executive Departments and Attorney General were there— The funeral was managed by the Members of the Bar and all the judges of the Supreme Court were present— There were also many members of both Houses of Congress and a large concourse of Citizens.— The procession went to the Eastern branch burying ground, and the body was deposited in the same vault where but one week since, were laid the remains at the House of Judge Bouldin— There was no religious service at the house, and only a short prayer at the grave, by Dr Post, in which the only qualities of the deceased which he noticed were his piety and religious faith— It was near three O Clock when we reached home, and for the rest of the day, I was unable to attend at all to any thing of the multiplicity of business in which I was involved— I could think of nothing, but William Wirt—of his fine talents—his amiable and admirable character— The twelve years during which we had been in close official relation together— The Scene when he went with me to the Capitol— His warm and honest sympathy with me in my trials, when President of the United States—my Interviews with him in January 1831. and his faithful devotion to the memory of Mr Monroe— These Recollections were oppressive
to my feelings— I thought there was due some public testimonial from me to his memory at this time— But Mr Wirt was no partizan of the present Administration— He had been a formal and dreaded Candidate, in opposition to the re-election of Andrew Jackson; and so sure is any thing that I say or do, to meet insuperable obstruction, that I could not imagine any thing that I could offer, with the remotest prospect of success. I finally concluded to ask of the House to-morrow morning to have it entered upon the Journal of this day that the adjournment was that the Speaker and members might be enabled to attend the funeral of William Wirt— I wrote a short address to the Speaker, to be delivered at the Meeting of the House, and endeavoured to concentrate in it, allusions to the remarkable excellencies in the character of Mr Wirt, in words as few as possible— It occupied me till near Midnight, and left me still anxious, lest I should say too little or too much, and still more so for the fate of my experiment.
21. VI:30 Friday.

I was still unable to bestow a thought this morning, upon any subject but that in which I was absorbed— I walked to the Capitol, and being there an hour before the Meeting of the House, I went into the Library and consulted Mallet’s History of Denmark, and Guthrie’s, and Malte-Brun’s Geography.— Before the House met, I asked the Speaker, if the Journal of the House would notice the decease of Mr Wirt, as being the occasion of the adjournment yesterday— He said no— I asked him if he could not have it so entered upon the Journal he said no— This I expected and I asked him if he would object to my asking the unanimous consent of the House that the entry should be so made— He said certainly not Accordingly when the House met, I made my proposal, and delivered my short Address of 5 minutes— It concluded with saying that as my proposal was not a fit subject for debate, if there should be an objection made to it, I wished him to consider it as withdrawn— The Speaker said he could not have the entry made, without the authority of the House, and he should consider it as granted if he should hear no objection made to it— Joel K. Mann, precisely the rankest Jackson man in the House said no— There was a general call upon him from all quarters of the House to withdraw his objection; but he refused— Blair of South-Carolina rose and asked if the manifest sense of the House could be defeated by one objection— The Speaker said I had requested that my proposal should be considered as withdrawn if obection should be made; but that the House was competent to give the instruction upon motion made— I was then called upon, perhaps by two thirds of the voices in the House—move—move—move—and said I had hoped the proposal I made would have obtained the unanimous assent of the House—and as only one objection had been heard, which did not appear to be sustained by the general sense of the House I would make the motion, that the addition should be made which I had proposed, in the Journal. The Speaker took the question and nine tenths at least of the members present, answered aye— There were three or four who answered no—and no division of the House was asked— The Reporters of the three Newspapers, immediately applied to me, for copies of my Address to the Speaker, and I gave the very draught, that I had made last Evening, to Mr Gales, who promised to have a proof of it sat in type for the National Intelligencer of to-morrow, and ready for my revisal, at the adjournment of the House— My anxious feeling was relieved.
Mardis’s Resolution about the Bank deposits was taken up, and he continued his Speech; much unheeded by me till the expiration of the hour— Private business followed, and the Bill for the relief of Susan Decatur, called forth Mr Patton of Virginia to sustain it. William J. Grayson, a new member from South-Carolina, spoke also in favour of the Bill Joseph H. Crane of Ohio opposed it; and was answered by James Parker of New-Jersey. Chilton of Kentucky took the floor against it, but as four O’Clock approached, the Committee of the whole, Connor Chairman, rose, reported progress, and asked leave to sit again— The House, after some struggle, suspended the rule, and adjourned over till Monday; to morrow being the Washington Birthday.— Warren R. Davis brought me to read a copy of a very pretty verses to a young Lady, and David Potts of Pennsylvania came to ask me what was to be done by the Antimasons about a candidate for the next Presidential Election— Mr Wirt having been their Candidate at the last— I said I thought their best policy would be to wait.— I called on my way home at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and found my Address already in type, with only one error of the Press which I corrected— He shewed me his two Napier Presses improved by Coe of New-York; each of which strikes off 1200 sheets in an hour— Also an Adams Press invented by a man of that name at Boston— I had evening visits from Edward Everett and Franklin Dexter; to the latter of whom I renewed, an invitation to dine to-morrow which he had declined— But he said he should be engaged at the Supreme Court all the morning, and was obliged to go off early the next Morning, so that he desired to be excused.
22. IV:30. Saturday.

I took to the Secretary of War, a Letter from James H. Bradford claiming a Pension for services and sufferings in the last War— Also a Letter from Dr Z. Bartlett, with Documents relating to the claims of John Burgiss William Burgiss and Solomon Churchill for Revolutionary War Pensions—they have already been twice or three times rejected; and I think will not fare better now.— I spoke also to the Secretary of War, of a Letter that I had received from a Professor at the West Point Academy, complaining that in the Appropriation Bill before the House of Representatives it is proposed to increase the Salary of the Professor of drawing, Mr Leslie, which would give him a rank over several other Professors unless a like increase should be allowed to them— Mr Cass said that the raising of the Salary of the Teacher of Drawing was desired by Mr Binney; who took great interest in it— That subsequently it had been proposed to make the Teachers and of Drawing Professors and to increase their Salaries; but it had not been introduced into the Appropriation Bill, and he had no expectation that it would succeed.— I then spoke of the Resolution offered by Alfred G. Hawes and now before the House for abolishing the Military Academy; and he said there would be a very heavy vote for it in the house— I observed that there was some discontent in the public at the changes which had lately been made in the Government of the Institution— He said it had never been in so good condition as at this time— That he remembered a remark I had made to Major Douglas, one day when
he called upon me with him, that the Government there was not sufficiently paternal— That was the error of Coll. Thayer, otherwise an excellent Officer.— But now under the present Superintendent Coll. De Rossi, the condition of the School was quite satisfactory— But whether it will turn out as good Officers is yet to be seen.— From the War Office, I went and gave a sitting to R. Peale for my Portrait— I had morning visits from G. M. Briggs and H. Hall, members of the House, and had afterwards company to dine— H. Binney, John M. Clayton, Harmar Denny, Franklin Dexter, Saml. L. Foot, James Hopkinson, R. M. Walsh, Daniel Webster and Mr Frye, were invited, and from various causes failed to come— After the company were gone we had Cards— W. C. Rives this day resigned his Seat in the Senate—having received from the Legislature of his State of Virginia, Instructions which he is not willing to carry into effect.
23. V:30. Sunday

Sultry weather with rain. In the Morning at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read Prayers, for the Second Sunday in Lent, and preached from Matthew 15.29. [“]And Jesus departed from thence, and came nigh unto the Sea of Galilee; and went up into a Mountain, and sat down there. 30. And great multitudes came unto him, having with them those that were lame, blind, dumb, maimed, and many others, and cast them down at Jesus feet; and he healed them: 31. Insomuch that the multitude wondered, when they saw the dumb to speak, the maimed to be whole, the lame to walk, and the blind to see: and they glorified the God of Israël.” In the afternoon at the Presbyterian Church, Mr Smith’s Sermon was from Matthew 16.24. [“]Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his Cross, and follow me.”— Mr Smith’s doctrine was that self-denial, was the most essential part of Religion; and most especially at this time and place— His tone was that of bitter complaint at the coldness for religion, and indifference for it in this city— There is no doubt great reason for his severity— Dr Naudain Mr Bell of New-Hampshire, Mr Elisha Whittlesey of Ohio with another Stranger, and Mr Wardwell of New-York were all in my pew— There were several other members of Congress at the Church and the House was unusually filled— I was barely able to write enough this Evening to bring up my arrears.
24. VI. Monday.

We had at the House, a repetition of the Scene of last Monday. It was the day for calling Petitions— Gorham Parks from Maine presented one from Bangor for the restoration of the deposits and the recharter of the Bank of the United States, and made a Speech against it. He was answered by John Reed of Massachusetts and by George Evans of Maine.— S. A. Foot of Connecticut presented a Memorial from New-Haven, and from two Banks in that State, for the restoration of the deposits and the recharter, of which he only stated the content, and moved the reference and the printing. Noyes Barber, presented a Petition to the same effect— C. C Cambreleng of New-York, presented a Petition, from Merchants of Salem, Massachusetts, praying for the Establishment of a Warehousing System, which was referred to the Committee of Ways and Means— David Potts of Pennsylvania, presented a Petition for the recharter of the Bank, with a very short Speech. Henry A. Muhlenberg of the same State presented a Memorial, signed by 1800 Petitioners in the County of Berks, for the restoration of the Deposits, and made a very
rancorous Speech against it— This gave rise to a debate of three Hours, in which M’Kennon, Watmough, Binney, Sutherland, Joel K. Mann and Miller of Pennsylvania, and Mercer, Burges, Mann and Turrell of New-York, Horace Everett, David Crockett, of Tennessee, Lane and Ewing of Indiana, and Ashley of Missouri took part— Muhlenberg stated that there had been imposition in getting up the Memorial, and read a Letter signed by nineteen of the Petitioners stating that they had been induced by misrepresentations to sign it— The Memorial was in German as well as English, but Muhlenberg had detached the German original from the rest, and offered only the English part— He called upon Muhlenberg to restore the German part and Watmough called for the printing of the names signed to the Petition. Mr Muhlenberg agreed to restore the German original, and the main debate turned upon the printing of the names— The question was taken by yeas and nays, and decided, by 112 to 90 to print the names.— It was past four when the house adjourned— Mr Gorham came and told me he was going to morrow Morning on private business to Boston; where he should stay not more than a week— In the Evening Mr W. B Reed of Philadelphia with a Son of R. Peters called to see me; came from Philadelphia yesterday, and are to return to-morrow. Mr Reed told me that he with Mr Joseph Ingersoll had commenced actions in the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania against the Proprietors of the Bordentown Railroad for Miss Whitehorn, Mrs Bartlett the Child, and Mr West— He said they should want my deposition and would take it, when I should pass through Philadelphia; if I would give him notice of the time two or three days before hand— Evening at Cards.
25. IV. Tuesday.

Immediately after the reading of the Journal, I asked the unanimous consent of the house to offer a Resolution, calling on the Secretary of the Treasury, for a Statement of the sums denominated in the Treasury Accounts, unavailable Funds, with various specifications An objection was made and I asked a suspension of the Rule—a vote was taken and stood 65 to 50. enquiry was made what the Resolution referred to; I asked that it should be read by the Clerk— It was read, and a second vote taken which stood 88 to 52. and the affirmatives not being quite two thirds of the members voting, my resolution was not received. Mr Mardis’s Resolution upon the distribution of the public funds among the State Banks was taken up, and he spoke till the expiration of the hour and concluded— The fortification Appropriation Bill was the first order of the day, with Mr M’Duffie’s motion to recommit the Bill to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, upon which there arose a sharp debate— The Speakers were Cambreleng, M’Kay of North-Carolina, Wayne, Pinckney of South-Carolina, Parker of New-Jersey and Vanderpoel— The Speaker successively made M’Kay, Parker, Pinckney and Polk sit down as being out of order; on a principle no better than his own caprice— He assumed that a Motion, to recommit a Bill at the third reading of a Bill, when it can not otherwise be amended, to a committee of the whole; admits of no debate upon the principles of the Bill; and he stopped every member who objected to any part of the Bill, as if he was undertaking to debate its principles— Polk the Chairman of
the Committee of Ways and Means, after feebly struggling for some time against the recommitment, and utterly unprepared to meet and answer any one objection to any item in the Bill, finally consented, and the Bill was recommitted, without dividing the House.— The Appropriation Bill for the Indian Department was next taken up— Motion was made by M’Kay of North-Carolina, for its recommitment to the Committee of Indian Affairs; but it was opposed by Horace Everett of Vermont, and Ashley of Missouri; and the recommitment was refused by a large Majority, and the house immediately adjourned— Evening Cards— My eyes were suffering and I could not write.
26. VI. Wednesday

James Harper, one of the members of the House from Philadelphia, asked the unanimous consent of the House to offer a Resolution—but objection was made, and he acquiesced without asking a suspension of the Rule— Mardis’s Resolution about the Deposits and the State Banks was immediately taken up, and William K. Clowney a new member from South Carolina spoke against it till the expiration of the hour when, upon motion of C. C. Clay the House passed to the Orders of the day— The Indian Department Appropriation Bill was the unfinished business of yesterday, and was immediately taken up and James M’Kay of North-Carolina now moved that it should be recommitted to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union for discussion and Amendment—this was strenuously resisted by Polk the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, and kindled a fiery debate of three hours— M’Kay insisted that there were several items of the Appropriations not warranted by Law nor by Treaty and particularly that there was an item of 21000 dollars which included both in this, and in the Indian Annuity-Appropriation Bill— This was at first positively denied, but M’Kay repeated the charge and produced proof of its truth from a manuscript tabular statement which had been furnished to the Committee of Ways and Means from the War Department— Polk could reply by nothing but generalities and assurances that the amount of the Appropriations was less than it had been last year— Cambreleng, M’Kinley, Beardsley and Sevier the delegate from Arkansas endeavoured to sustain Polk, against the recommitment, which was now assented to by Horace Everett, of the Indian Committee, and urged by Fillmore, A. G. Hawes, C. F. Mercer, L Williams, Vinton, Coulter and Wilde of Georgia— The debate became exceedingly personal— Beardsley of New-York, to rally the party feeling, threw out a suspicion that there was insidious design lurking under the motion for recommitment; and that there was a project for tacking to some Appropriation Bill, a recharter of the Bank of the United States— In making this remark he pointed particularly to Coulter of Pennsylvania, who was in high Spirits, and who replied with great indignation, and no measured use of epithets, closing with a general remark that any man capable of imputing dishonest motives to others without evidence to support him could be no other himself than a rascal—a word which he pronounced with an emphasis quite electrical— Wilde of Georgia, who felt annoyed by Beardsley’s insinuation answered him with more polish, but with equal keenness of edge, and Mercer said he would not reply to him, were it only from motives of mere humanity— Beardsley turned upon Mercer and Wilde with retorted scorn, but somewhat bewildered aim—and he disclaimed
any intention of imputing insidious purposes to Coulter— The debate closed by a crowing declaration of Coulter, that if the Gentleman from New-York was satisfied he was so.— He wished it only to be understood that no man should tread upon his toes without his levelling at least a lance against him— The question was taken by yeas and nays, and the Bill recommitted to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union by a vote of 106 to 103. Adjourned past 4— My eyes grievously suffering— Whist.
27. IV:30. Thursday.

Mr Harper of Philadelphia asked again the unanimous consent of the House to offer his Resolution— Objection was made; and he moved the suspension of the rule but it was denied. Mardiss Resolution was resumed, and Mr Clowney continued his Speech to the expiration of the hour, without finishing— He gave something of the retort Courteous to the sarcasms of Mr Wise who was not in his seat— He has gone home perhaps to hold Conference with his Constituents— On passing to the orders of the day, C. F Mercer obtained a suspension of the Rule to take up a Bill from the Committee of roads and Canals, of which he is Chairman, for building a bridge across the Potowmack— There were two Motions of Reference: one to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union—the other to the Committee on the District of Columbia, of which Joseph W. Chinn is chairman— There had already been some debate on this question, and it was now renewed and continued for about two hours— The Speakers were Mercer, Rencher, M’Kennon, Fillmore and M’Duffie for reference to the Committee of the whole on the Union, and Chambers, Stewart, Stoddert and Wayne for the District Committee— The House decided for the Committee of the whole— Next came an engrossed Bill to provide for the Settlement of certain Revolutionary Claims, which like many others had crept to the third reading without opposition, and apparently without observation It was now opposed by Franklin Pierce a new member and young man from New-Hampshire, who spoke about half an hour, very handsomely against it— He was followed on the same side by Aaron Vanderpoel from New-York, who has been impatient on various occasions to obtain the floor— He had spoken for about ten minutes, when without finishing he gave way for a motion to adjourn, about four— I walked home, and idled away the Evening having eyes in no condition to read or write— Coll. Campbell an old member from South-Carolina, but who has been some years out of Congress took his Seat, this day; elected to supply the place of Thomas D. Singleton deceased— The nomination of four Government Directors of the Bank of the United States, which has been two months pending in the Senate was this day rejected—
28. IV. Friday.

At the House Thomas H Hall of North-Carolina, obtained the unanimous consent of the House to offer a Resolution— It was that the Committee of Ways and Means should be instructed to enquire into, and report upon the expediency of reducing the revenue to the necessary expenditures of the Government, and called for the yeas and nays upon the question which was immediately made whether the House would consider the motion
I asked what was the motive of the member to offer this Resolution at this time— The Speaker said it was not in order to debate the question of consideration— The House refused to consider the motion 70 to 115— I voted against it— Mr Harper of Philadelphia asked again the consent of the House to offer his Resolution, but objection was made, and he did not move the suspension of the rule— Mardis’s Resolution about the deposits, and the Banks came up, and Clowney finished his Speech against it.— The orders of the day, Bills upon private business followed the House went into Committee of the whole on sundry Bills, Connor of North-Carolina in the Chair— There was a Bill for the relief of Edmund Brook, which upon question made by me, had been postponed, and upon which I was not yet prepared to vote—it was again postpone— It was a bill to authorize Brook to bring two Slaves into the District, from the State of Virginia, by an exemption from the Law prohibiting such introduction of Slaves— Mr Chinn Chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, who had reported the Bill, came and asked me if I had satisfied myself with regard to the prohibitory law— I said I had not examined it, and asked him where it was to be found— He said it was an old Statute of Maryland; passed in the year 1794— The Bill for the relief of Susan Decatur, was debated till near four O’Clock—opposed by Hawes and Hardin of Kentucky, and supported by an eloquent Speech of H. L. Pinckney of South-Carolina, who mingled as usual much nullification and the bloody Bill with his argument— The South-Carolinians do this now to a ludicrous degree. When Hardin finished the Committee rose and reported several Bills which passed to be engrossed. Wayne obtained a suspension of the rule to move an adjournment over to Monday—upon which the yeas and nays were demanded and refused— It was to give the Committee of Ways and Means time to prepare their report upon the Secretary of the Treasury’s reasons for removing the deposits—adjourned between 3. and 4.— Mr Edward Everett brought me a Letter from Caleb Cushing a Royal Arch Mason, and Member of the Massachusetts Legislature to Mr Webster— This Gentleman had written to enquire what was the reason, of their delay to act upon the Resolutions respecting the distress, and removal of deposits, and recharter of the Bank. Cushing answers, bitterly complaining that they are paralyzed by the Anti Masons, who upon all occasions vote with the Jackson party— And enquires if I could not do something to heal this breach?— I said I had done every thing in my power, and if any thing had been done to conciliate the Antimasons, they would have met every advance in the same Spirit— But Mr Cushing must look to himself and his party, for the failure of all my endeavours to conciliate— I had given fair notice and warning both to Governor Davis, and Mr Webster from both of whom I had received encouraging assurances of conciliation to the Anti-Masons—instead of which every possible thing had been done to fret and exasperate them— All their Candidates for the Senate had been swept off the board— Not one Anti-Mason had been elected to the Council— A fraudulent Law against unlawful Oaths was now in concoction to baffle and deceive them—and just now the Senate had refused to grant to the joint investigating Committee the Power to send for persons and papers—And now their aid was implored to pass National Republican Resolutions in favour of the Bank.— It was impossible for me to do any thing more with them, and I did believe they would go over to Jacksonism— I had done all I could to prevent it, but in vain.
Day— Much as last Month— I am slackening at my rising hour, and wasting unprofitably my industry, without any discernable prospect of doing good.
